repnme.cdata!:
Easing Armenia's transition to a
            market economy

abstracts.cdata!:
With independence in 1991, Armenia
            suffered a severe economic contraction. Between 1990 and
            1993, GDP dropped by more than 50 percent. This led to
            hyperinflation, a budget deficit that reached a high of 55
            percent, factory closures, little electricity supply, and
            large-scale emigration. About 80 percent of the population
            survived on humanitarian assistance and more than half the
            population lived below the poverty line.

docna.cdata!: Transicion de Armenia hacia una economia de mercado

display_title.display_title:
Easing Armenia's transition
            to a market economy : Transicion de Armenia hacia una
            economia de mercado

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of both the First and Second
            Structural Adjustment Credit (SACs) projects was
            satisfactory. The operations met the major objectives, and
            sustainability is likely. The lessons learned indicate that
            a highly educated background among policy people, is key for
            a smooth and comprehensive reform program, as is the
            continuity of both the counterpart and Bank's teams,
            conveying far greater ownership. The composition of
            supervision teams, when comprised of the core country team,
            has the advantage of ensuring that SAC supported policies
            will be directed towards sectoral priorities. Furthermore,
            it is suggested that frequent supervisions by the core
            country team, may be possible under the same SAC budget,
            since the costs may be distributed among other sectoral
            projects under their administration, in addition to the
            added leverage advantage, off the adjustment operations
            funds, to support their respective sector projects. The
            pressure for financing gaps on tranche releases, may affect
            policy considerations for their release, as was the case
            with the second SAC operation. Thus, special consideration
            should be given to premature releases, which may well weaken
            compliance with the reform program. It is further suggested
            to focus on intensive supervision, namely in new member
            countries, to gain familiarity with Bank operations.

docna.cdata!:
Armenia - First and Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Projects

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - First and Second
            Structural Adjustment Credit Projects

repnme.cdata!:
Armenia - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This Second Structural Adjustment Credit
            for Armenia supports the government's program to
            consolidate macroeconomic stability and to lay the
            foundations for sustained private-sector led growth over the
            medium term. The program includes measures to: 1) improve
            financial discipline in the private and public sectors, so
            as to increase domestic savings, facilitate further external
            adjustment, and ensure Armenia's creditworthiness; 2)
            accelerate the growth and development of the private sector;
            and 3) ensure the social sustainability of the reform
            process and preserve Armenia's stock of highly-skilled
            human capital. The government's strategy to improve
            financial discipline is based on actions in three critical
            areas: strengthening its resource mobilization capacity,
            deepening energy sector reforms, and extending these reforms
            into other critical, energy-consuming public utilities. To
            accelerate private sector development, the government will
            focus on completing privatization, strengthening the banking
            sector, and developing capital markets. The credit supports
            measures to improve targeting of social benefits and to
            strengthen the social safety net. The program also includes
            actions to reform the public pension system, introduce
            private pensions schemes, and ensure adequate and affordable
            long-term protection to the elderly. Lastly, the credit
            supports health and education reforms, which have as a
            primary goal ensuring equitable access to essential services.

docna.cdata!:
Armenia - Second Structural Adjustment
            Credit Project

display_title.display_title:
Armenia - Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project
